title: Does a narcissist ever regret walking away? - Quora

response.answer_text: I feel like there is an implication in your question that regret is accompanied by personal loss and shame, or something deep. One of the hallmarks of NPD is an inability to face blame. The reasons for this are kind of complex and little bit outside of this question, but rest assured, shallow as it seems, they can’t help this, it is a disorder after all. Interpersonal interactions have a very different purpose for narcissists, so their version of regret is much simpler: i.e. anger at a loss of control, boredom due to withheld supply, etc. They can’t experience love like more neurotypical folks can, so they never feel a deep sense of loss from not seeing someone. The fix they get from any given person, even a prized primary supply, is always predicated on maximizing self-serving benefits. They don’t empathize, etc. If a narcissist walks away from anything, a couple things (and any combination) are possible: They are boredThey have met someone they perceive as more interesting, or someone who will make them look and feel betterThere is some sort of specific benefit available for them, anything from familial, personal, professional; those things are generally not compartmentalized for narcissists the way they are for others.They are initiating a trauma part of the trauma-bond cycle and plan on hoovering the person back, causing psychological instability they hope to take control ofThey don’t care either way about the person but are banking that their powers of manipulation will be able to get the supply back if necessaryThe last thought I have about narcissists in regards to ending of relationships is that, despite the way their actions seem to indicate a cavalier attitude, they actually really fear abandonment. For narcissists, pretty much all relationships are assumed to be an open door; other people are supposed to be perpetually available for their enjoyment, until those people, likely sick of abuse, make it clear that they aren’t. This is when the narcissist experiences a bruised ego and uses it to endlessly siphon supply. They milk every bit of it they can from playing the victim, even after they’ve abused. In this case, the person they’ve split with is basically “black” to them (I’ve heard a few narcs use this expression). This is a result of the lack of whole object relations that is a cornerstone of the disorder. If they’re the one controlling the discard and they walk away, the only way they might maybe “regret” things (momentarily) is if you move on to bigger better things and you're still on ok terms. I can guarantee the narcissist will be back if you let them, to benefit from being in close proximity with your success. But they’ll be gone as fast as they came when something else comes along. Hope this helps.

(sorry “taker”) (purely by grace, double -digit DEMANDING it as a right). . I would give my eye teeth to know what goes through that mind these days. Thinking about it I funnily enough actually,, still being silly enough to care a bit for her, I feel sorry for her because I put myself in the suppose situation (faint possibility) that, say just oneday she would look back and see the psychological damage she has caused and come face to face with the sin-guiltiness of her negligence of her sister… then how will that feel.???? Good also at constantly creating new friendships they stay with just long enough to use and short enough not expose their true selves and won't hesitate to spit in the eye of anyone who sees through them (little social shining lights that attract others) but seem happy with the flightiness of temporary friendships, so long as the friendships leave themselves at the top of the tree.. Or they're gone. This person was a middle child and suffered from rejection all her life. That's the only reason I feel sorry for her. That reason.

Regret is the wrong word since narcs by nature NEVER take responsibility for anything. They deny, deflect and create whatever narrative that suits their needs. I recall my ex-wife “regretting leaving her agent” after her new agent dumped her after two months—when the reality was her previous agent left her! If they walked away and their circumstances turn, a narc will easily try to win back it’s previous victim to fill the need. They get a high from duping their victim into believing their false narrative and promises of changing, only to repeat the abuse even worse afterwards for making the narc work so hard in winning you back. It’s all a never ending cycle of abuse, love bombing and more abuse until you finally give up… or wake up and walk away—and go NO CONTACT.

As soon as you do better without them. Why? Because they don’t want you to be happy. They don’t want you to get over them. Even if they don’t want you, they don’t want someone else to have you. So, it’s not regret as you feel it - they don’t regret it because they realize how special you were, or how good of a person. They simply regret it because they’ve lost control and influence of you.

In a word, no, and there is really no need. If the narcissist should ever find him/herself without supply, he/she will just look up a favorite - or available - previous supply, and simply hoover, until new supply is discovered. It’s like visiting an old friend, but with ulterior motives, and no intention of commitment.

sure. if you win the lottery, they’ll regret it. if they can’t replace you with someone as good or better, they’ll regret it. if they miss out on something good because they left, they’ll regret it. if walking away negatively affects them, they’ll regret it. it’s all about them, you know.
